items.text: 主语 + 谓语 + 宾语
items.title: Subject + Verb + Object (SVO)
items.comment: The most fundamental sentence structure in Mandarin Chinese.

items.title: Example: I eat apples.
items.comment: 我 (wǒ) = Subject, 吃 (chī) = Verb, 苹果 (píngguǒ) = Object.

items.title: Subject + (hěn) + Adjective
items.comment: Used to describe a subject with an adjective. The verb 'to be' (是) is generally not used before adjectives; '很' (hěn) is often used for smoothness, not necessarily 'very'.

items.title: Example: He is tall.
items.comment: 他 (tā) = Subject, 很 (hěn) = adverb (often used before adjectives), 高 (gāo) = Adjective.

items.text: 主语 + 谓语 + 宾语 + 吗？
items.title: Subject + Verb + Object + 吗 (ma)?
items.comment: Formed by adding the question particle 吗 (ma) to the end of a statement to make a yes/no question.

items.title: Example: Do you eat apples?
items.comment: 吗 (ma) turns the statement into a yes/no question.

items.text: 主语 + 不/没 + 谓语 + 宾语
items.title: Subject + 不/没 + Verb + Object (Negative Sentences)
items.comment: 不 (bù) negates present/future actions or states; 没 (méi) negates past actions or existence.

items.title: Example: I don’t eat apples.
items.comment: 不 (bù) is used for present negation.

items.title: Example: I didn't eat apples.
items.comment: 没 (méi) is used for past negation.

items.text: 主语 + 有/是 + 宾语
items.title: Subject + 有/是 + Object (Possession/Equivalence)
items.comment: 有 (yǒu) means 'to have'; 是 (shì) means 'to be' and is used for equivalence or identification.

items.title: Example: I have a book.
items.comment: 有 (yǒu) expresses possession.

items.title: Example: This is my book.
items.comment: 是 (shì) expresses identification, combined with the possessive '的' (de).

items.title: 这/那 + 是 + Noun (Demonstratives)
items.comment: 这 (zhè) means 'this'; 那 (nà) means 'that'.

items.title: Example: This is an apple.
items.comment: Using '这' to point to 'this'.

items.title: Example: That is a book.
items.comment: Using '那' to point to 'that'.

items.title: Subject + 在 (zài) + Location (Location/Being At)
items.comment: 在 (zài) means 'to be at' or 'in'.

items.title: Example: Where are you?
items.comment: 哪里 (nǎlǐ) or 哪儿 (nǎr) are used for 'where'.

items.title: Example: I am at home.
items.comment: 家 (jiā) means 'home'.

items.text: 时间表达 + 主语 + 谓语 + 宾语
items.title: Time Expression + Subject + Verb + Object (Time Placement)
items.comment: Time expressions usually come before the subject or immediately after the subject.

items.title: Example: Today, I eat apples.
items.comment: 今天 (jīntiān) is the time expression.

items.text: 主语 + 谓语 + 得 (de) + 形容词/副词
items.title: Subject + Verb + 得 (de) + Adjective/Adverb (Degree of Action/Result)
items.comment: 得 (de) connects a verb to a complement describing the manner or result of the action.

items.title: Example: He eats quickly.
items.comment: 很快 (hěn kuài) describes how he eats.

items.text: 主语 + 要 (yào) + 谓语/名词
items.title: Subject + 要 (yào) + Verb/Noun (Expressing Want/Intention)
items.comment: 要 (yào) expresses desire, intention, or a future action.

items.title: Example: I want to drink water.
items.comment: 要 (yào) + verb phrase.

items.title: Example: Do you want to eat apples?
items.comment: Asking about desire.

items.title: Subject + 会 (huì) + Verb (Expressing Ability/Future)
items.comment: 会 (huì) means 'can' (skill/ability) or 'will' (future event).

items.title: Example: I can speak Chinese.
items.comment: Expressing an acquired skill.

items.title: Example: He will come.
items.comment: Expressing a future event.

items.text: 主语 + 可以 (kěyǐ) + 谓语
items.title: Subject + 可以 (kěyǐ) + Verb (Expressing Permission/Possibility)
items.comment: 可以 (kěyǐ) means 'can' (permission) or 'it is possible'.

items.title: Example: Can I study here?
items.pinyin: wǒ kěyǐ zài zhèlǐ xuéxí ma?
items.pronounce: wuh kuh-yee dzai juh-lee shwe-shee ma?
items.comment: Asking for permission.

items.title: Subject + 想 (xiǎng) + Verb (Expressing Desire/Thinking)
items.comment: 想 (xiǎng) means 'to want to' (a less strong desire than 要) or 'to think'.

items.title: Example: I want to go to China.
items.comment: Expressing a desire or intention.

items.text: 主语 + 地点 + 谓语
items.title: Subject + Location + Verb (Verb preceded by Location)
items.comment: The location of an action often comes before the verb.

items.title: Example: He reads books in the library.
items.comment: 图书馆 (túshūguǎn) is the location, placed before the verb 看 (kàn).

items.title: Subject + Verb + 了 (le) (Completion of Action)
items.comment: 了 (le) indicates the completion of an action or a change of state.

items.title: Example: I have eaten.
items.comment: Indicates the action of eating is completed.

items.title: Example: It's raining now. (It started raining.)
items.comment: Indicates a change of state (from not raining to raining).

items.title: Subject + Verb + 过 (guo) (Past Experience)
items.comment: 过 (guo) indicates that an action has been experienced at least once in the past.

items.title: Example: I have been to China.
items.comment: Indicates the experience of going to China.

items.title: Subject + Verb + 着 (zhe) (Continuous Action/State)
items.comment: 着 (zhe) indicates a continuous state or action.

items.title: Example: He is wearing clothes.
items.comment: Describes the continuous state of wearing clothes.

items.text: 疑问代词替换 (谁/什么/哪里/几/多少)
items.title: Interrogative Pronoun Questions (Who/What/Where/How many/How much)
items.comment: Interrogative pronouns directly replace the unknown part of the sentence.

items.title: Example: Who is your teacher?
items.comment: 谁 (shéi) replaces the subject.

items.title: Example: What do you buy?
items.comment: 什么 (shénme) replaces the object.

items.title: Example: Where is your home?
items.comment: 哪里 (nǎlǐ) replaces the location.

items.title: Example: How many books do you have? (for numbers under 10)
items.comment: 几 (jǐ) for small quantities.

items.title: Example: How much is this? (for larger quantities/money)
items.comment: 多少 (duōshǎo) for larger quantities or money.
